 King James Version: "know them."
 
 Revised Standard Version: "know them."
 
 New International Version: "have sex with them."

The preliminary treaty began with a signing on 4 November, 1796 (the end of George Washington's last term as president). Joel Barlow, the American diplomat served as counsel to Algiers and held responsibility for the treaty negotiations. Barlow had once served under Washington as a chaplain in the revolutionary army. He became good friends with Paine, Jefferson, and read Enlightenment literature. Later he abandoned Christian orthodoxy for rationalism and became an advocate of secular government. Barlow, along with his associate, Captain Richard O'Brien, et al, translated and modified the Arabic version of the treaty into English. From this came the added Amendment 11. Barlow forwarded the treaty to U.S. legislators for approval in 1797. Timothy Pickering, the secretary of state, endorsed it and John Adams concurred (now during his presidency), sending the document on to the Senate. The Senate approved the treaty on June 7, 1797, and officially ratified by the Senate with John Adams signature on 10 June, 1797. All during this multi-review process, the wording of Article 11 never raised the slightest concern.  The treaty even became public through its publication in The Philadelphia Gazette on 17 June 1797.

 First, I will point out that "finding the meaning of things" is activism. Though I do feel that both activism and strict constitutionalism have their places in our courts.
 
 However, looking to tradition is a very bad way of determining the intentions of an amendment. Those writing a particular amendment are not likely factoring in tradition in any fashion during their writing of it, and looking at tradition should therefore reveal nothing about their intentions.
 
 What we should do is interpret the reasons an amendment is written as it is. Consider the fourteenth amendment, for example, the equal protection clause specifically. It was certainly included to prevent any state from denying equal protection of the laws to blacks. Yet we can see that it does not specifically mention blacks. The fact that it does not mention blacks indicates that it was intended to any groups who might be discriminated against.
 
 Now if there were some other group that they had in mind, laws discriminating against that group would have been removed immediately along with laws discriminating against blacks. But it was certainly only laws discriminating against blacks that were removed. It logically follows then that this clause was intented to protect groups discriminated against in the future, groups who the authors were not yet able to name specifically but who might appear in the future.
 
 Understanding this, it does not make sense to suggest that this amendment couldn't apply to homosexuality because of a tradition opposing homosexuality. There is no indication that this amendment was meant to be bound by tradition. It was meant instead to apply to all people, all groups, even those which tradition has discriminated against.
 
 But consider what the fourteenth amendment would say if it did factor in tradition. If we can consider the enforcement of traditional notions of sexual morality a rational basis, why would we be unable to consider the enforcement of traditional notions of racial superiority to be one? As I stated, this amendment was not intended to be bound by tradition. It was intended to remove the discrimination that we have traditionally caused.
 
 And what good reason is there to look to tradition in the first place? It is understandable, in my opinion, to consider freedom, equality, happiness, and that which is in the best interest of the people when interpreting the Constitution. We might even consider the writings of those who created an amendment in order to determine its meaning.
 
 But why tradition? If we can show that a tradition has caused undue discrimination and oppression, has targetted a minority unjustly, should we really continue that simply because we've always done it in the past? Does that really make any sense at all? I submit that it makes none, and that any judge who rules to harm a minority based not on the Constitution, not on the principles behind the Constitution, and not on the best interest of the people is a judge who has failed in both his legal and moral duties.
 
 It is a judge's duty to protect the rights guaranteed in the Constitution, and to make this nation a better place for everyone. So when a judge rules to continue to oppress, to continue to harm, simply because we've always done so in the past, that judge is wrong.
